review.title: Small Representations of Big Kidney Exchange Graphs
review.abstract: Kidney exchanges are organized markets where patients swap willing but incompatible donors. In the last decade, kidney exchanges grew from small and regional to large and national---and soon, international. This growth results in more lives saved, but exacerbates the empirical hardness of the $\mathcal{NP}$-complete problem of optimally matching patients to donors. State-of-the-art matching engines use integer programming techniques to clear fielded kidney exchanges, but these methods must be tailored to specific models and objective functions, and may fail to scale to larger exchanges. In this paper, we observe that if the kidney exchange compatibility graph can be encoded by a constant number of patient and donor attributes, the clearing problem is solvable in polynomial time. We give necessary and sufficient conditions for losslessly shrinking the representation of an arbitrary compatibility graph. Then, using real compatibility graphs from the UNOS nationwide kidney exchange, we show how many attributes are needed to encode real compatibility graphs. The experiments show that, indeed, small numbers of attributes suffice.
histories: Preliminary version appeared at the 31st AAAI Conference on Artificial Intelligence (AAAI 2017)

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: There are more than 100,000 needy patients waiting for a kidney transplant in the United States, with similar - and growing - demand worldwide. (In addition to potential cadaveric transplantation via the deceased donor waiting list, a recent innovation - kidney swapping (Rapaport 1986; Roth, So � nmez, and U � nver 2004) - allows patients with willing living donors to participate in cyclical donor swaps or altruistic donor chains to obtain a life-saving organ. Kidney swapping now accounts for more than 10% of living donors in the U.S., with that percentage increasing annually. In reality, participating patients and donors are endowed with a number of attributes: blood type, tissue type, age, insurance, home transplant center, travel readiness, and myriad other metrics of health, personal preferences, and logistical constraints that can change at cost temporarily or permanently.

sections.heading: 2 A New Model for Kidney Exchange
sections.text: In this section, we formalize our model of renal exchange. We demonstrate that within the framework of this model, certain known NPhard problems in general renal exchange can be solved in polynomic time. We also show that determining the best attributes for change (at a certain cost) in polynomic time can be solved by creating a compatibility graph.

sections.text: While patients and donors in a kidney exchange are endowed with an initial set of characteristics, in practice it may be possible to change a number of these attributes to effect the final adjustment. For example, the human body naturally tries to reject a transplanted organ to varying degrees - but at a certain cost to the overall health of the patient. sections.heading: 4 Computing Small Representations of Real Kidney Exchange Compatibility Graphs
sections.text: In this section, we test our hypothesis that real compatibility graphs can be represented by a much smaller number of attributes than the theoretical worst-case results of Section 3. We begin by introducing general mathematical programming techniques to determine whether a given graph G = (V, E) can be represented, and then use real and generated compatibility graphs from UNOS-wide kidney exchange to show that a small k is sufficient for (k, 0) representations, and conclude by researching the approval of larger thresholds t to match size. sections.heading: 5 Conclusions & Future Research
sections.text: Motivated by the increasing size of real kidney exchange, we presented a compact approach to modelling kidney exchange compatibility diagrams. Our approach is closely related to the classical theory of crossing diagrams and can be considered as the first research and practical application of p-section diagrams. We provided necessary and sufficient conditions for lossless reduction of the representation of an arbitrary compatibility diagram in this model. However, real compatibility diagrams are not arbitrary and are created based on the characteristics of patients and donors. Using real data from the US-wide kidney exchange of UNOS, we demonstrated that the use of only a small number of attributes is sufficient to represent real diagrams. This observation is of potential practical importance; if real diagrams can be represented by a constant number of attributes, then central hard NP problems in general kidney exchange are resolved (in general kidney exchange).
